Situation1: They openly turn to each other for help in a difficult personal moment.
Expectation2: Participate in project planning and provide accurate time estimates
Situation2: Management needs firm estimates for the quarterly roadmap and is awaiting their input
Story:
My phone buzzed just as I was reviewing the project timeline for the new software release. It was a message from my younger brother: “Can you talk? I really need you.” He never asked for help unless it was serious. My heart twisted—I knew he’d been struggling since his breakup, and as his sister, I wanted to be there, to listen, to support him like we always promised we would.

But at the same time, my manager’s email sat unread in my inbox, subject line: “Need your estimates by 3 PM for the roadmap meeting.” The team was waiting on me to finalize the planning, and I knew how critical my input was. If I delayed, the whole project could slip, and everyone was counting on me to be precise and reliable.

I stared at my phone, torn. My brother’s name glowed on the screen, a silent plea. My calendar notification pinged, reminding me of the looming deadline. The weight of both expectations pressed down on me, and I felt myself pulled in two directions, unable to ignore either call.
